Award.AwardTitle: DEVELOPING A PROCESS-BASED UNDERSTANDING OF THE FACTORS CONTROLLING THE SEASONAL FORMATION OF PEDOGENIC CARBONATE
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Timothy M. Gallagher has been granted an NSF EAR Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out research and education plans at the University of Texas at Austin. The investigation will focus on understanding the seasonal formation of carbonate minerals in soils. The project will consist of three components: laboratory experiments, computer modeling, and application of experimental and modeling results to a geological problem. The anticipated results will be of interest to a wide range of disciplines including those within the earth, biological, and soil sciences. Throughout this fellowship period Dr. Gallagher will actively convey the importance of environmental change to the general public through participation in events such as the University of Texas K-12 oriented Forty Acres Fest. In addition, he will mentor graduate students and develop and supervise independent research projects for undergraduates. Dr. Gallagher will co-teach an undergraduate environmental isotope geochemistry course, developing new assignments designed to expose students to the power and utility of computer modeling.

The research project will take the novel approach of pairing experimental soil manipulations with cutting-edge reactive transport modeling in order to gain a thorough understanding of processes driving
pedogenic carbonate formation. The research plan will include (1) experimental manipulation of soil columns where different seasonal patterns of precipitation are simulated, (2) use of reactive transport models to place the experimental results of the research into a quantitative and predictive framework, and (3) application of the experimental and modeling results to a geologic case study centered on pedogenic carbonate derived paleoelevation histories of Andean uplift. Carbonate minerals in soils are an important archive of past environmental conditions, that is widely used by the scientific community for reconstructing past climatological, ecological and tectonic changes. The accuracy of these paleo-reconstructions is hindered, in large part because the processes controlling the seasonal timing of pedogenic carbonate formation have not been fully characterized. It is expected that this investigation will contribute to this knowledge gap.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary outcome of this work is the development of a methodology for near-continuous measurements of soil gas. This data permits observation of carbonate mineral dissolution and formation in soils. Specifically, high-precision measurements of oxygen and carbon dioxide allow for mineral dissolution and formation signals to be separated from other soil processes, such as respiration.

As part of this project, both small-scale laboratory experiments and intermediate-scale outdoor experiments were conducted to assess when and why carbonate minerals are likely to accumulate in soils. Results from the laboratory experiments both validated the new methodology and contributed important findings. For example, a simulated rainfall experiment demonstrated how short-term events can drive significant amounts of carbonate dissolution and formation. These results have implications for the use of soil carbonate as a climate archive as well as for ongoing efforts to understand dryland carbon cycling. For example, when only soil carbon dioxide is monitored in modern soils, the carbon fluxes into and out of the soil can be significantly under- or over-estimated depending on if soil carbonate is forming or dissolving. Carbon isotope measurements during these experiments also demonstrated that gas in soil pore-space can behave differently than typically assumed, which has important implications about how soil gases are modelled.

Another component of this project was the design and installation a long-term outdoor soil carbonate experimental station at the University of Texas Stengl Lost Pines Biological that will continue to operate for years to come. This station consists of twelve soil pits that were instrumented with soil moisture and temperature sensors, soil gas wells, and soil water sampling devices. A gas analyzer and custom-built autosampler system were installed to continuously monitor gas compositions. These field scale experiments enable the study of the effects of seasonal weather patterns and vegetation on soil carbonate formation.

Computer simulations were also conducted to refine interpretations of existing geological datasets. For example, soil gas compositions were modeled for paleosol carbonate records from the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum, a significant warming event in the geologic past. This work demonstrated that oxidation of methane in soils cannot explain the observed trends. Furthermore, the increase in soil respiration rates required to explain the observed trends are too large to be explained by rising temperatures alone. This observation may indicate a change in the seasonality of soil carbonate formation.

As part of this postdoctoral fellowship, personal development work included giving guest lectures, developing laboratory exercises for geochemistry courses, and acquisition of new analytical techniques. I also supervised the participation of multiple undergraduate students from underrepresented groups within this research project. This has included both semester long research experiences for two undergraduates and field excursions for multiple others.
